II. 

INTRODUCTION

The Royal Government of the Kingdom of Bhutan established skills training institutes as
2. 
part  of  its  program  to  modernize  the  education  system  in  the  early  1960s.  The  Asian
Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  provided  assistance  since  the  mid-1980s  to  the  technical  and
vocational education and training (TVET) sector in, for example, establishing the Royal Institute
of Management2 and expanding the Royal Bhutan Polytechnic to improve the quality of training
and  double  the  intake  capacity.3  Following  ADB-initiated  policy  dialogue  in  the  1990s,  the
Government  embarked  on  reform  of  the  TVET  sector  to  meet  the  needs  of  an  economy  in
transition  to  a  modern,  private-sector-led  market  economy,  and  established  the  National
Technical  Training  Authority  (NTTA)  in  1999,  as  recommended  in  ADB  technical  assistance.4
During  the  initial  operation  of  NTTA,  the  Government  recognized  the  urgent  need  for
employment-oriented skills training at the basic level and requested ADB financial assistance to
prepare  the  Basic  Skills  Development  Project.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance
(PPTA) was approved in December 1999 and implemented between June and December 2000.
The Fact-Finding Mission from 8 to 19 January 2001 and the Appraisal Mission5 from 15 March
to  2  April  2001  visited  Bhutan  to  formulate  the  Project  on  the  basis  of  consultations  on  the
project  feasibility  report  with  NTTA  and  other  Government  agencies,  representatives  of  the
beneficiaries (parents, students, and future employers), nongovernment organizations (NGOs),
and international aid agencies, as well as extensive site visits by staff during the PPTA review.
The project framework is in Appendix 1.

Between  1984  and  1996,  the  adult  literacy  rate  increased  from  28  percent  to  54  percent,  and
the primary school gross enrollment rate (grades 1-6) rose from only 12 percent in 1980 to 72
percent in 1996. The Government is targeting a 95 percent enrollment rate in primary schools
under the 8FYP (1997-2002), and full enrollment at junior high school (grade 8) by 2007, at the
end of the 9FYP. In 1999, over 107,000 students were enrolled in the general education system
consisting  of  254  primary  and  community  schools,  51  junior  high  schools,  21  high  schools,  7
private schools, and 10 other institutions providing specialized education as well as tertiary and
vocational  training.  Since  1997,  the  number  of  teachers  has  trebled  and  the  number  of
educational  establishments  has  doubled.  Throughout  this  development,  the  education  sector
has aimed to improve the gender balance. Currently, the ratios in favor of boys are about 55:45
in  primary  schools,  53:47  in  junior  high  schools,  57:43  in  high  schools,  and  52:48  in  private
schools.7 In 1996, the female primary school enrollment rate was about 60 percent.

The  Department  of  Education  (DOE)  of  the  Ministry  of  Health  and  Education  (MOHE),

administers Bhutan’s current general educational system. While DOE directly administers higher
education,  direct  financial  and  administrative  responsibility  for  primary  and  secondary  schools
has been devolved to the dzongkhag (district) administrations. Formal schooling begins at the
age of six and is offered free of charge up to the tertiary level (except in seven private schools).
In the public schools system, the Government provides textbooks and, in some places, boarding
facilities and meals. Rural primary and junior high school students also receive free stationery.
Communities  in  rural  areas  contribute  labor  for  building  and  maintaining  their  schools.
Notwithstanding the contribution by individuals/families, the Government bears over 90 percent
of the recurrent costs of all schools, and 80 percent of the capital costs of primary schools and
100 percent of secondary schools.8

The  Government  established  NTTA  in  May  1999  to  coordinate  the  national  TVET

Government  also  established  the  National  Employment  Board  (NEB)  in  March  2000  with  the
mandate  of  regulating  and  administering  the  labor  market.  The  mandate  includes  preparing

Before  the  establishment  of  NTTA,  the  Technical  and  Vocational  Education  Section
8. 
under DOE coordinated the training programs. The relatively large capacity of the public sector
to absorb all employment in the past—which partly explains the current aspirations of educated

agencies.  Consequently,  the  Royal  Civil  Service  Commission  (RCSC)  administered  job
placements for the public sector agencies, but there was no agency to facilitate private sector
employment. There was also no central agency to coordinate a national TVET system, involving
the  formulation  and  planning  of  a  skills  development  policy,  skills  standardization,  testing  and

develop the private sector, lack of these capabilities constrains the promotion of private training
institutes in the TVET sector or in-house staff development programs run by individual private
enterprises.

3. 

Demand for Skills Training14

Since  the  early  1960s,  Bhutan  has  implemented  policies  to  shift  from  a  traditional
17. 
economy  to  a  modern,  market-based  economy.  In  the  last  two  decades,  Bhutan's  economy
grew in real terms at the annual rate of 8.0 percent in the later part of the 1980s, 5.6 percent
from  1991  to  1995,  and  6.0  percent  from  1996  to  1999,  due  to  industrialization  and
diversification of its economic activities. Agriculture declined from a share of 53 percent of the
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  in  1981  to  37  percent  in  1998;  and  industry,  led  by
manufacturing, electricity, and construction, increased from 17 percent in 1981 to more than 35
percent in 1998. Since the second half of the 1980s, private sector development was a priority
of the Government and major State-owned enterprises were privatized. The buoyant growth of
the industry sector in the 1980s and 1990s created increasing demand for modern skilled and
semiskilled  workers.  Although  the  Government  had  given  high  priority  to  human  resource
development, particularly in the general education sector to support its modernization program,
domestic  skilled  human  resources  were  not  well-developed.  To  meet  the  rapidly  increasing
demand from the industry sector, the Government resorted to the large pool of migrant workers
from neighboring countries to fill the vacancies of skilled, semiskilled, and unskilled workers.

Rationale

IV. 

THE PROJECT

Since 1981, Bhutan has experienced robust economic growth while diversifying from a
46. 
traditional subsistence economy to a modern economy. This growth has been accompanied by
significant growth in modern sector employment, particularly in construction, manufacturing, and
business services. However, Bhutanese youth lack appropriate skills, and have been unable to
take  advantage  of  these  employment  opportunities.  Substantial  investment  in  basic  education
over the past several decades has produced a large cohort of educated youth, many of whom
have  remained  unemployed  despite  the  existing  employment  opportunities.  Unless  these
graduates  can  be  provided  with  employable  skills,  they  face  an  uncertain  future  with  little

will  be  unable  to  utilize  its  domestic  human  resources  to  promote  national  development,  and
social  problems  associated  with  a  growing  pool  of  unemployed  urban  youth  are  bound  to
increase. The TVET system is poorly positioned to provide the high-quality training required by
the  growing  private  sector.  The  Government  plans  to  upgrade  the  TVET  system  by  improving
the policy framework of the system; upgrading the quality and relevance of training; expanding
access, particularly for women and the rural villagers who currently do not have access to skills
training; and improving the system’s responsiveness to private sector demands.

Objective and Scope

The project seeks to improve the quality and relevance of the TVET system to enable it
47. 
to  provide  employment-oriented  basic  skills  training  to  new  school  graduates,  unemployed
youth, domestic laborers, people in rural areas, particularly women and the poor. Such training
will give the target groups access to employment and income-generating opportunities and will
expand  the  capacity  to  provide  skilled  human  resources  to  promote  private  sector  growth  as
well as to meet the demand for skilled workers in the private sector. To achieve the objective,
the  Project  will  (i)  strengthen  the  institutional  capacity  for  policy  making,  planning,  and
coordination  in  the  TVET  sector,  and  for  delivering  basic  skills  training  relevant  to  the  market
needs  and  commensurate  with  the  capacity  of  the  beneficiaries;  (ii)  increase  access  to  basic
skills  training  by  expanding  the  TVET  system  to  include  community-based  programs,  and
rehabilitating  existing  and  establishing  new  facilities;  (iii)  improve  the  quality  of  basic  skills
training by increasing links with the private sector; and (iv) promote effective utilization of basic
skills by developing employment guidance and placement services. The Project will have three
components.

Timely Implementation. The Project starts with (i) development of policies and physical

110.  Demand for Skilled Labor. Sustained growth of the private sector with rising demand
for trained labor is one of the important assumptions for the success of the Project. Although the
Project will provide skills to Bhutanese with career aspirations for working in the private sector, if
labor demand shrinks due to insufficient growth of the private sector, the Project’s development
impact and sustainability will be weakened.

The COS indicates the shortage of skilled Bhutanese as one of the five constraints to the
111. 
growth of the private sector, and hence the economic growth of Bhutan. To avoid the future risk
of  insufficient  demand  for  skilled  workers,  ADB  should  promote  concerted  efforts  and  policy
dialogue with the Government in various sectors to promote the economic growth of the country
including  support  to  (i)  improve  policy  setting  and  financial  intermediation;  (ii)  improve  road
transport and power supply; and (iii) strengthen vocational, technical, and basic skills during the
project implementation period as indicated in ADB’s country assistance plan for 2001-2003.

To  effectively  cope  with  the  emerging  needs  from  the  growing  private  sector,  the  new
112. 
TVET  system  should  have  management  that  effectively  responds  to  the  changing  operational
environment. To ensure efficacy and efficiency of the TVET system, the Project will strengthen
management by (i) providing modern managerial skills and control system; (ii) institutionalizing
working linkages with private enterprises, including setting up such organizations as ITCs and
IPU  and  promoting  private  sector  participation  in  training  by  apprenticeship  and  the  training
consignment  system;  and  (iii)  developing  a  reliable  labor  market  monitoring  and  assessment
system.  Mechanisms  to  enhance  private  sector  participation  in  the  new  TVET  system  are
summarized in Appendix 14.

113.  Demand  for  Training  by  Educated  Youth.  The  attitude  of  the  educated  Bhutanese
toward  both  a  public  sector  career  and  private  sector  employment  is  changing.  Due  to  the
limited prospects of  (i) being recruited into the public service due to the Government policy to
limit the size of the civil service, and (ii) finding suitable employment in the industry sector due to
lack of employable skills, Bhutanese youth are already seeking basic skills training. To further
promote the change in attitude, the Government in the mid-1990s established NEB to assist in
job  placements  in  the  private  sector,  and  introduced  work  value  education  throughout  the
general education system. In support of the proposed new Government policies, an IPU will be
established  in  NTTA  under  the  Project  to  implement  the  school-industry  exchange  programs
and  several  publicity  works  by  organizing  workshops  and  utilizing  newspaper,  radio,  and
television  programs,  web  and  e-mails,  and  other  media;  and  JPO  in  NEB  to  offer  career
guidance  and  job  placement  services  for  employment  in  the  private  sector.  To  promote  work
value education at the school level, the Project will also strengthen vocational center facilities in
secondary schools nationwide.

114.  Other Demand-Related Risks. In addition to these demand-side risks (para. 110-113),
other  risks  for  project  sustainability  exist:  the  inflexibility  of  the  training  provided,  and  the
changing  demands  of  the  private  sector  as  it  develops  and  progresses  towards  a  modern
industrial economy (policy risk), or the capital requirements necessary to replace equipment due
to  changing  demand  (capital  risk).  It  is  crucial  that  the  training  system  develop  the  ability  to
quickly  adapt  and  evolve  with  the  changing  requirements  of  industry.  This  requires  strong
linkages  with  the  private  sector.  To  institutionalize  private  sector  linkages,  the  Project  will
establish  four  key  TVET  policies  including  the  private  sector  partnership  policy  at  the  outset.
The  capital-intensive  nature  of  TVET  has  been  deemed  an  inherent  weakness  of  the  TVET
system. The Project will challenge this risk by introducing innovative cost sharing schemes such
as consigning training operations to private sector institutes by contract. Under the consignment
system, NTTA will develop training programs and, if necessary, procure training equipment for

 30

rent,  while  the  contracted  private  training  institutes  will  use  their  own  premises  to  conduct
training using the programs and equipment rented from NTTA.
